title: 6 Best Cordless Vacuums of 2025, Tested and Reviewed by AD
description: Thoroughly refresh all floor types—no strings attached
author: Nashia Baker, Yelena Moroz Alpert
excerpt: These are the best cordless cleaners our editors and contributors rely on for untethered deep cleaning. Shop our top picks from Samsung, Levoit, Dyson, and more
text: All products featured on Architectural Digest are independently selected by our editors. However, we may receive compensation from retailers and/or from purchases of products through these links.Featured in this articleBest Overall Cordless VacuumSamsung Bespoke Jet Cordless Stick VacuumRead moreFor Pet ParentsBissell PowerClean FurFinder Cordless VacuumRead moreBest Combo CleanerShark HydroVac MessMaster Cordless Wet-Dry VacuumRead moreThe best cordless vacuums are your secret weapons for a hands-on approach to cleaning your floors without a power cord—we think it’s one of the most ingenious innovations in the world of cleaning since the original hoovers were created in the 1860s. While the vacuum industry is besting itself over the years, including robot helpers with AI capabilities, cordless vacuums are not lagging behind thanks to slimmer, more streamlined bodies, longer run times, and upgraded wet-dry features.“Cordless vacuums provide a convenient and lightweight cleaning solution, allowing easy mobility between rooms without the need for a new power source,” says Katie Dills, brand president of The Cleaning Authority. “They offer similar capabilities to other vacuum types, making them versatile for various cleaning needs.” And, Dills says these vacuums are ideal for busy parents and older individuals, since they eliminate the risk of tripping over a cord.Scroll down for more advice from Dills and other experts on the need-to-know information about the best cordless vacuums. But first, here are our favorite picks—tested and reviewed—from AD’s go-to appliance brands. Bonus: Most are on sale.Best Overall Cordless VacuumSamsung Bespoke Jet Cordless Stick VacuumSelf-standing, space-saving designLong runtimePlenty of accessoriesSelf-empty clean stationMost expensive model on the listWeight: 6.3 poundsBattery life: 100 minutesBin capacity: 0.5 gallonsAccessories? YesThe Samsung Bespoke Jet, while a superior vac, has a hefty price tag, making it more suitable for the best splurge category among our top picks. The space saving design allows the vacuum to sit inside of the clean station. If you want a vacuum cleaner setup that doesn’t look like a vacuum cleaner setup—this is it. The combination of the design and the satin black finish make it look like a work of art—contributor Terri Williams doesn't even put it in the closet when not in use.The vacuum cleaner has a dual brushroll that can be used on carpet and hard floors, LED lights on the floor head so she can see in the dark, and a 100-minute run time that allows her to finish vacuuming in one session (while the convenient display also shows me how much battery life is remaining). The AI cleaning mode can detect the floor type and automatically change the suction power accordingly.It’s got an adjustable telescopic wand and accessories like an anti-tangle pet hair tool, crevice tool, and combination tool to pick up debris on non-floor areas as well. The self-empty clean station even keeps Williams from having to touch the dust bin (it automatically opens and closes when she places the vacuum on it and touches the button.For Pet ParentsBissell PowerClean FurFinder Cordless VacuumPopout canisterLightweightWorks on hardwood floors​​LED headlightsNot ideal for high-pile area rugsWeight: 7.1 PoundsBattery life: 40 minutesBin capacity: 0.5 LitersNoise Level: Charging dock, FurFinder upholstery tool, 2-in-1 dusting brush/crevice toolA cordless model is pretty much a must if you have pets—it’s hard enough to clean without the cords when fur balls are involved. Cue the Bissell PowerClean FurFinder, a self-standing stick vacuum with a tangle-free illuminated head, multiple attachments, and three suction levels (goodbye, allergens!). AD senior commerce SEO analyst Stewart Savin tried it to clean up pet messes: dog hair, crumbs from treats, as well as dirt and leaves that her pup, Dexter, tracks in. “I was simultaneously horrified and satisfied by how much dirt and hair it picked up,” she says in her review. “This cordless stick vacuum makes my weekly chore a bit less daunting, and that makes a big difference to me.”The lithium-ion battery life is a huge perk—40-minute run time on a single charge—and makes a huge difference in Savin’s cleaning routine. With a 200W motor, this cordless stick vacuum has strong suction and can even pick up larger debris. “The vacuum and charger require such a small amount of storage space that it’s easy to leave in a spare bedroom,” Savin adds.Best Combo CleanerShark HydroVac MessMaster Cordless Wet-Dry VacuumSelf-cleaning designWorks on hardwood floorsSmall charging station​​LED headlightsLoud when in useDoesn’t self-dryNeed to remove extra debris manuallyWeight: 8.46 PoundsBattery life: N/ABin capacity: 0.38 QuartsNoise Level: 2 multi-surface concentrate solutions (12 oz. ), 2 brushrolls, foam filter, and charging dockPick up a Shark’s HydroVac MessMaster wet-dry vacuum if you’re looking for something multifunctional without the heft. Several AD team members have tested this cleaner and stand behind its maneuverability and versatility. “Since my home is covered with tile, this Shark vacuum has been a big help in picking up and scrubbing virtually any mess that makes its way to my floors,” says senior commerce editor Nashia Baker in her review of the best vacuums on Amazon. “I seamlessly navigate it through my home with its narrow, cordless design and pivoting motorhead to get into tight spaces.”Contributor Yelena Alpert is all about the LED headlights that highlight every spec of dirt and debris. “I have dark hardwood floors and it’s amazing how well the debris blends in, that is until the light exposes the mess,” she says. This lightweight cordless vacuum weighs under nine pounds, so even little helpers can maneuver it. “My kids actually fight over who gets to use it,” Alpert adds. “I love that it can make chores fun.”While the vacuum is most helpful on hard floors, you’ll have no problem with area rugs during your cleaning session. Another tester, Williams notes that this upright vacuum is incredibly intuitive thanks to a smart display that lets you know the battery life and the amount of cleaning solution left in the vacuum.Once you’re done, launch the self-cleaning cycle. You want to do this every time you use the wet-dry vacuum. Baker says that it’s pretty quick (about 10 minutes or so), but do keep in mind that the process is a bit noisy. Alpert keeps the charging dock in her cleaning closet (which has an outlet) so the noise level does not bother her. She does say that you may need to open up the canister to remove bigger clogs. This Shark cordless vac lacks a self-drying feature so it’s not a bad idea to remove the rollers to air dry and prevent a musty smell.The Budget PickLevoit LVAC-300 Stick VacuumEasy assemblyStylish designLong-lasting batteryThe suction power in eco-mode isn’t too strongWeight: 6.61 poundsBattery life: 120 minutesBin capacity: 0.75 litersNoise Level: 77.5 dBWhile Williams has tested the LVAC-200 in the past and given it rave reviews for its filtration system and tangle-resistant design, associate commerce director Lori Keong says the newest Levoit product, the LVAC-300 vacuum, takes it up a notch with a longer runtime (up to 60 minutes vs. 50) and a redesigned brush assembly for reduced tangling. Plus, its tech-friendly design is top-notch. “I love that the display screen tells you exactly how much battery life is left, and I was able to vacuum the entirety of my teeny apartment around 300 square feet without even breaking 90% battery life on eco mode,” Keong says. It did lose some cleaning points for the power suction of eco mode, which struggled to pick up a popcorn kernel, but she says turbo mode had it covered.It has a small footprint and intuitive assembly design, as Keong says it arrived in a “box small enough that I questioned how the whole thing fit in there.” From there, the setup was a breeze. She recommends this vacuum for those who want the look and quality of a Dyson cleaner at a lower price point. “I think it’s a great alternative for anyone who’s on a budget and wants a slightly tech-enhanced model that deconstructs for small space living.”Best HEPA FilterTineco Pure ONE Station 5 Cordless Smart VacuumSelf-standing clean station12-stage filtration systemLED headlightGreat battery lifeWeight: 16.5 poundsBattery life: 70 minutesBin capacity: 2.5 litersAccessories? YesThe Tineco Pure ONE Station 5 Smart Cordless Smart Vacuum is a more economical choice than the Tineco Floor One S7 Combo, which is another pick on our list. It’s not a wet-dry vacuum, and doesn’t include as many accessories as the former, but does have plenty of features. The two-in-one crevice dusting brush, and the ability to convert from a cordless stick to a handheld adds functionality for other cleaning scenarios. The Pure ONE Station 5 also has a 70-minute battery, which is very good. The brush roller, which has a LED headlight, works on both hard floors and carpet, and the 175W suction captures dust and debris. (We also considered the Tineco Pure One S11.)The large brush roll resists tangling hair and pet fur, which eliminates the need to stop and pull items off the brush—and also eliminates a clogged pipe. The best part is the fully sealed automatic dust collection process. After docking the stick vac on the cleaning station, it will automatically self-clean, which means you don’t have to manually open and clean the dustbin. The auto clean process includes cleaning not only the dustbin, but also the brush, tube, and the HEPA filter.The 12-stage filtration system is actually the most impressive part. The vacuum itself has a six-stage filtration system (main cycle, mess filter, dura-cycle, coarse sponge, fine sponge and HEPA 13 filter). And then, the clean station has its own six-stage filtration system (main cycle, mess filter, single cyclone, coarse sponge, fine sponge, and HEPA 13 filter).Great for HardwoodsDyson Gen5detect Absolute VacuumFluffy optic clean head for hardwoodsWhole-machine HEPA filtrationNo touch bin emptyingWall-mounted storage onlyWeight: 7.72 poundsBattery life: 70 minutesBin capacity: 0.2 gallonsAccessories? YesDyson vacuums are well represented on our list of the best vacuums for hardwood floors, and we really like the Dyson V15 detect—however, the company released a new model, the Dyson Gen5detect Absolute, which is the most powerful of the company’s HEPA cordless vacuums. Williams likes the single-button power control over the trigger mechanism. Also, the 70-minute battery life is not only good, but the longest among Dyson’s cordless vacuums. The vacuum has a fluffy optic cleaner head that not only cleans but also polishes hard floors.In addition, the Dyson Gen5 Detect Absolute has a Digital Motorbar cleaner head (which has 56 detangling vanes to remove wrapped hair) and a hair screw tool attachment (for car seats, pet beds, and stairs). However, Williams finds herself using the built-in dusting and crevice tool, which fits in tight spaces to pick up debris, and the combination tool, which has a wide nozzle and brush for cleaning vents and other areas. This is one of the best Dysons, one of the best vacuum cleaners, and one of the best cordless stick vacuums (but wall-mounted storage is your only option).Eureka Stylus Elite NEC490BL Cordless Stick Vacuum CleanerLay flat designLightweight bodyLED Headlights3 power levelsSelf-empty stationQuality doesn’t measure up to higher-priced modelsWeight: 6.34 poundsBattery life: 60 minutesBin capacity: 0.6 litersAccessories? YesThere’s a difference between a cheap vacuum and a budget-friendly vacuum that’s still a good value. The Eureka Stylus Elite Cordless Vacuum Cleaner falls into the latter category. Usually hovering around the $200 mark, it’s a great choice for the price, especially when you can find it on sale. The self-empty station for hands-free dust bin emptying is a particularly desirable feature in this price range. To be clear, the vacuum does not have the same high-quality feel as, say, a Samsung, LG, or Dyson. However, it doesn’t feel cheaply made either: Think of it as a Toyota, instead of a Mercedes Benz.The 350W motor provides sufficient power to effectively remove dust and debris from both hard floors and carpet. The crevice tool and two-in-one upholstery tool also increase the vacuum’s functionality, since it can used as a handheld to clean my car, or with the tube/pole to clean Williams’ ceiling vents and more. There are three modes: low, mid, and high, with the battery life hovering around 60 minutes. (Keep in mind that with all cordless stick vacuums, battery life is stated for the lowest mode, and using a higher mode decreases how much time is left before you’ll need to stop and charge the battery.)Shark Cordless Vacuum Cleaner with HEPA Filter2 brushrollsFlex wandGreat runtimeOdor neutralizerWeight: 18.48 poundsBattery life: 70 minutesBin capacity: 0.74 quartsAccessories? YesA self-emptying feature is becoming more popular with the newest vacuum models, and Shark, always a step ahead in vacuum technology, already included one in an earlier model which we’re replacing with this Shark Cordless PowerDetect Clean & Empty. It has an anti-allergen complete seal with True HEPA filtration. This self-empty system eliminates dirty hands, clouds of dust, and allergens. It’s bagless, for those who don’t like to replace bags. Instead, the container holds up to 45 days of dust and debris. There’s also an odor neutralizer cartridge that can be placed into the vacuum’s brush roll and is designed to keep foul odors out of the air while cleaning.Shark vacuums are always rated highly on our list, and it was a toss-up between this model and the Shark Stratos to wind up on this list, but we chose this one because it’s Shark’s strongest cordless suction vac, and includes the auto-empty system.While the vacuum does not have a LED light on the brush roll, it has something most vacuums don’t: two brush rolls. So, whether I’m going in a forward motion or in reverse, the vacuum does an excellent job of picking up hair and other debris on any floor type - whether bare floors of carpet. This is a result of the direction detect feature. There’s also another “detect” feature. Powerdetect automatically boosts suction power when I’m on carpet or when dirt is detected on hard floors. In addition, the multiflex wand bends in half, making it easy for me to vacuum far under couches. The 70 minute runtime is also impressive and accessories include a crevice tool and pet multitool to pick up any pet hair on upholstery.BISSELL CleanView XR Pet 300w Lightweight Cordless Vacuum3 cleaning modesTangle-free brushrollFur brush for petsWall mounted storage onlyWeight: 8 poundsBattery life: 40 minutesBin capacity: 3 litersAccessories? YesBissell is known for vacuums geared toward pet owners, and the Bissell CleanView XR Pet continues the tradition. We chose its inclusion for several reasons—the tangle-free brushroll keeps hair from getting wrapped around it and the LED lights on the floor head make it easy to see into dark spaces on both hardwood floors and carpet, where hair and other debris could be hiding. One of the attachments is a deep cleaning fur brush, which can be used to remove pet hair from upholstery, cars, stairs, and other areas (wall mounted storage is your only option for this vacuum cleaner).Williams doesn't have pets, but she's found the vacuum does a good job when it needs to pick up hair, dirt, and other items. The 40-minute runtime is average, but the three cleaning/suction power modes (standard, medium, turbo) make it easier to choose the most effective setting, depending on the floor surface.Miele Triflex HX2 Cordless Stick VacuumDurable buildMovable power unitLifetime HEPA filterWeight: 8 poundsBattery life: 60 minutesBin capacity: 0.5 litersAccessories? YesGerman manufacturer Miele is known for vacuum cleaners built to last, and the Miele Triflex HX2 is no exception, warranting it a spot on our list of the best cordless vacuums. While most of the cordless vacuums on this list can transform into a handheld vacuum, the Miele Triflex HX2 is unique: The power unit can be attached at the top of the vacuum cleaner (convenient when Williams wants to clean under furniture), but the power unit can also be attached near the bottom, which takes the weight off of the top making it easier and faster to cover large areas.The suction power can be adjusted to one of three levels using the slide control and the vac uses a HEPA lifetime filter, which retains 99.999% of dust captured.Dreametech R20 Cordless Vacuum CleanerTouchless dust releaseFlexible adapter for vacuuming under furniturePlenty of accessoriesWall-mounted storage onlyWeight: 10.1 poundsBattery life: 90 minutesBin capacity: 0.6 litersAccessories? YesThe multi-surface brush on the Dreame R20 Cordless Vacuum Cleaner, combined with the strong suction (190AW), can get deep into carpets to pick up and remove debris and pet hair. The flexible adapter also allows the vacuum to bend so that it can fit under furniture without having to bend over (in other words, it bends so you don’t have to!). But that’s not the only cool accessory: The vacuum cleaner also has a soft roller brush for hard floors, a motorized mini-brush, wide combination tool, and crevice nozzle for conversion into a handheld vacuum.The 90-minute runtime is good, and it provides plenty of time to vacuum even large homes, while the LED screen lets you view your selections and battery life, while the LED Optic Illumination consists of blue lights on the floor head that reveal dust on the floor. Emptying the vacuum only requires one press of the button, and does not require you to touch the dust and debris, Williams says.What to Look forThese are some of the features and factors to keep in mind as you shop for one of the best cordless vacuums.Battery life: “It’s important to consider the life of the battery, which can usually last from 20 minutes to over an hour on a single charge—if you have a larger space to vacuum, a longer runtime would be preferable,” advises Marla Mock, president of Molly Maid.Dills agrees, explaining that cordless vacuums are more convenient because you can freely clean around your home without worrying about an outlet. “However, since cordless vacuum batteries do need to be recharged, you may not be able to clean as large of an area as you would with a corded vacuum,” she adds. If you live in a large home and vacuum often, Dills says you’ll definitely want to consider options with a longer battery life, so you won’t have to keep taking the vac back to the charging dock.In fact, Alessandro Gazzo of Emily Maids considers batteries to be the biggest weakness with cordless stick vacuum cleaners. “Because cordless vacuums are so thin and compact, they don’t really have enough space for a good-sized battery.” Gazzo recommends looking for vacuums with two batteries that you can swap—and she says each battery should last at least 30 minutes.And here’s something else to keep in mind as you consider battery life: manufacturers tend to provide estimates based on the lowest or the eco power setting. So, if you’re vacuuming on a higher power setting, expect the battery to drain faster, resulting in a shorter cleaning session, before you need to recharge it. Also, most batteries need to be on the charging dock for hoursWeight: The vacuum’s weight may also be an important factor, since it can contribute to ease of use or be a hassle to move. “A lightweight and ergonomically-designed model can significantly ease the cleaning process, making it less of a chore,” says Tim David, CEO at Airlucent. “It's especially important for cleaning stairs, upholstery, or high areas where maneuvering a bulky vacuum (like one with a canister) can be tedious.” Especially if you’re a pet owner, or if you plan or vacuuming some areas, like the living room, every day.However, keep in mind that you may need to find a balance. According to Gazzo, a light weight doesn’t necessarily mean more premium. “Many vacuum cleaners are lighter because they’re using cheap plastic,” she explains. “There’s a balance between quality and weight, and I would stay in the six to nine pound area, again, considering the quality is worth it.”Surfaces: “Cordless stick vacuum cleaners are designed to clean a variety of floor types, including hardwood floors, carpeted floors, rugs, tile, and laminate floors, and also stairs, and furniture (like couches and chairs),” says Mock.But if you have carpet floors and rugs, Gazzo recommends spending a bit more to get a vacuum with high suction power. “For hard floors, look for soft roller cleaner heads because ‘standard’ cleaner heads sometimes scratch the surface, especially on delicate floors,” she says.Suction: David tells us that suction power is the heart of a vacuum's performance. “Pick a model with strong enough suction to effectively pick up dirt for the floor that you are going to use it on,” he explains. “Carpets and rugs will need a strong suction, whereas hard floors could be effective with less suction.”Also keep in mind that the average cordless vacuum might have strong suction, but it’s not going to compare to upright vacuums.Dustbin size: When deciding what size bin would be suitable, Dills says you should consider factors like pets, home size, and how frequently you intend to vacuum. Mock says options generally range from 0.3 liters to 1.5 liters in capacity.” Smaller dustbins are suitable for quick clean-ups and small spaces,” she says. “Larger ones are preferred for larger homes or spaces and require less emptying during cleaning sessions.”How We TestedLike all of the categories across AD Shopping, we thoroughly test and review in the appliance sector too. Our team of editors and contributors welcome top-of-the-line vacuums ranging from wet-dry to steam cleaners into our homes on a regular basis to assess how well they keep our floors clean. For these cordless vacuums, we’ve tested all of them for at least one week and some for years to ensure these home appliances hold up for the long haul. We also factored in the below to determine if the cleaners in this guide were worthwhile investments.HEPA Filters: Our favorite cordless vacuums feature HEPA filters, which are designed to capture even the smallest of particles and allergens (usually around 99.97%). This filtration system ensures that your floors are getting their most thorough clean, while also ridding your space of irritants like dust that can cause allergy flare-ups.Warranty: Since vacuums tend to be bigger-ticket appliances, we checked for options that boast generous warranties. We looked for options with at least one year returns available in the event that there are any issues or malfunctions.Suction and Airflow: Arguably the most important factor in a vacuum, we kept an eye out for cleaners with strong suction power and airflow to effectively pick up dirt and debris without having to go over our floor areas with several passes.Cleaner Heads: Since every home is bound to have some tight spaces and nooks that are hard to reach, most vacuums in this list have motorized brush rolls as well as rotating cleaner heads to thoroughly clean and navigate through your space. Plus, many cleaner heads are designed to get right up against baseboards to collect dust.Ease of Use: Bottom line, we’re fans of intuitive vacuum cleaners that are simple to put together out of the package and use on a routine basis. While some boast smart features like AI technology to scope out the dirt on your floors from your phone, we deem them all as user-friendly appliances.How to Care for Cordless VacuumsIt might seem counterintuitive to clean a cleaning appliance, but it’s a must to make sure your cordless vacuum is long-lasting. Read on for the best maintenance tips to follow.Attachments: From crevice to combination tools, you’ll need to clean any and all attachments that come with your cordless vacuum to make sure they stay in their best condition. Many can be cleaned using gentle soap and water, but check the manufacturer guidelines to follow any specific cleaning techniques.Clogs: Oftentimes brushrolls can experience clogging, which typically prevents airflow and suction altogether. While some vacuums notify you when there’s a clog, manually check after each deep clean by removing the brush roll to make sure nothing is jammed behind it.Dust Bin: Many vacuums will also alert you when the dustbin is full. However, emptying it regularly—even before it’s at capacity—can help ensure the vacuum’s suction power stays at its strongest. Dump it directly in a trash can to help prevent excess allergens from filling the air.Filter: Wash the filters within the vacuum and be sure to follow the manufacturer’s instructions since every vacuum is a little different. Many companies recommend replacing HEPA filters every one to two years.FAQsWhat is the best and most powerful stick vacuum?The best and most powerful stick vacs are the Samsung Bespoke Jet AI and Dyson Gen 5. Both are built with high quality and durable components. These also excel in power and boost suction power as needed. The multi-surface brushrolls swivel well, and can clean well on both carpets and hard floors. In addition, the three vacuums use HEPA filtration, ease of use is excellent, and the vacuums are versatile enough to convert to a handheld vacuum. We also consider the Shark, Bissell, and Tineco models on our list to be some of the best cordless vacuums. Still, if we had to choose three, those would be our top choices.Is a Shark or Tineco cordless vacuum better?One brand is not necessarily better than another one, so the choice should be based on what’s more important to you. For example, both the Shark and Tineco models are self-cleaning and have a LED headlight, which is useful if you have to get into corners and under furniture. The Shark HydroVac is aimed at quick cleaning sessions and is a more affordable model. Tineco Pure ONE has a 70-minute runtime but weighs almost twice as much as the Shark, and does have a self-emptying clean station. The Tineco also has a HEPA filtration system;. on the other hand, the Shark has two brushrolls, and a flex wand for reaching under furniture. Weighing which features are more important to you can determine which cordless stick vacuum is better for your needs.Which vacuum cleaner has the best battery life?The Samsung Bespoke Jet AI provides 100 minutes on a single charge, so it has the longest battery life without swapping out batteries. At its heels, the DREAME R20 Cordless Vacuum has a battery life of 90 minutes. And Tineco Pure ONE can extend your cleaning session to 70 minutes.What else is important in battery life?Several cordless stick vacuums are ideal for pet hair. The Bissell PowerClean FurFinderoffers the right combo of power, suction, and lights to see hidden pet hair. The dust canister traps pet hair so the mess doesn’t spill when you have to empty the dust bin. The Samsung Bespoke Jet is another powerful option that has an anti-tangle pet hair tool for removing pet hair from various surfaces. The Dyson Gen5 Detect Absolute has a digital motorbar cleaning head with 56 detangling vanes to remove wrapped hair, along with a hair screw tool attachment for pet beds. Last but not least, the Bissell Cleanview Pet has a tangle-free brushroll, LED lights on its floor head, and a deep cleaning fur brush.How do you clean a cordless stick vacuum?Specific instructions may vary by manufacturer and model, but as a general rule, you should remove and empty the dust bin (if it’s not a self-cleaning vacuum) into the trash and clean any trapped debris. Remove and rinse the filters or wash with soapy water according to directions. Clean the brush heads and accessories by first removing any debris, and then rinsing under running water. Never submerge the main body containing the motor in water.What are the best cordless stick vacuums for pet hair?Several cordless stick vacuums are ideal for pet hair. The LG Cord Zero offers the right combo of power, suction, and lights to see hidden pet hair. The compressor also packs pet hair down so you don’t have to stop and empty the dust bin so often. The Samsung Bespoke Jet is another powerful option that has an anti-tangle pet hair tool for removing pet hair from various surfaces. The Dyson Gen5 Detect Absolute has a digital motorbar cleaning head with 56 detangling vanes to remove wrapped hair, along with a hair screw tool attachment for pet beds. Last but not least, the Bissell Cleanview Pet has a tangle-free brushroll, LED lights on its floor head, and a deep cleaning fur brush.What is a good suction power for a cordless vacuum cleaner?The last thing you want is a vacuum cleaner that can’t actually pick anything up. That’s where the suction power comes in. For cordless stick vacuums, look for air watts (AW)---it measures suction power and air flow. Ideally, a solid model should have at least 100 AW, but if you have pets, you want this metric to be at least 150 to 200 AW.What should you keep in mind about vacuum cleaner accessories?Many of the vacuum cleaners on our list come with replacement brushes and specialty cleaning solutions. While it may seem like a nuisance to replace these, you’re actually extending the life of your vacuum and its cleaning abilities. Updating accessories, such as roll brushes, is especially valuable when you invest in a higher line model. Keep in mind that cleaning solutions are usually made specific to each brand and model. Trust us: You don’t want to end up with a sudsy disaster by adding in the wrong floor cleaner.

What to Look for

These are some of the features and factors to keep in mind as you shop for one of the best cordless vacuums.

Battery life: “It’s important to consider the life of the battery, which can usually last from 20 minutes to over an hour on a single charge—if you have a larger space to vacuum, a longer runtime would be preferable,” advises Marla Mock, president of Molly Maid.

Dills agrees, explaining that cordless vacuums are more convenient because you can freely clean around your home without worrying about an outlet. “However, since cordless vacuum batteries do need to be recharged, you may not be able to clean as large of an area as you would with a corded vacuum,” she adds. If you live in a large home and vacuum often, Dills says you’ll definitely want to consider options with a longer battery life, so you won’t have to keep taking the vac back to the charging dock.

In fact, Alessandro Gazzo of Emily Maids considers batteries to be the biggest weakness with cordless stick vacuum cleaners. “Because cordless vacuums are so thin and compact, they don’t really have enough space for a good-sized battery.” Gazzo recommends looking for vacuums with two batteries that you can swap—and she says each battery should last at least 30 minutes.

And here’s something else to keep in mind as you consider battery life: manufacturers tend to provide estimates based on the lowest or the eco power setting. So, if you’re vacuuming on a higher power setting, expect the battery to drain faster, resulting in a shorter cleaning session, before you need to recharge it. Also, most batteries need to be on the charging dock for hours

Weight: The vacuum’s weight may also be an important factor, since it can contribute to ease of use or be a hassle to move. “A lightweight and ergonomically-designed model can significantly ease the cleaning process, making it less of a chore,” says Tim David, CEO at Airlucent. “It's especially important for cleaning stairs, upholstery, or high areas where maneuvering a bulky vacuum (like one with a canister) can be tedious.” Especially if you’re a pet owner, or if you plan or vacuuming some areas, like the living room, every day.

However, keep in mind that you may need to find a balance. According to Gazzo, a light weight doesn’t necessarily mean more premium. “Many vacuum cleaners are lighter because they’re using cheap plastic,” she explains. “There’s a balance between quality and weight, and I would stay in the six to nine pound area, again, considering the quality is worth it.”

Surfaces: “Cordless stick vacuum cleaners are designed to clean a variety of floor types, including hardwood floors, carpeted floors, rugs, tile, and laminate floors, and also stairs, and furniture (like couches and chairs),” says Mock.

But if you have carpet floors and rugs, Gazzo recommends spending a bit more to get a vacuum with high suction power. “For hard floors, look for soft roller cleaner heads because ‘standard’ cleaner heads sometimes scratch the surface, especially on delicate floors,” she says.

Suction: David tells us that suction power is the heart of a vacuum's performance. “Pick a model with strong enough suction to effectively pick up dirt for the floor that you are going to use it on,” he explains. “Carpets and rugs will need a strong suction, whereas hard floors could be effective with less suction.”

Also keep in mind that the average cordless vacuum might have strong suction, but it’s not going to compare to upright vacuums.

Dustbin size: When deciding what size bin would be suitable, Dills says you should consider factors like pets, home size, and how frequently you intend to vacuum. Mock says options generally range from 0.3 liters to 1.5 liters in capacity.” Smaller dustbins are suitable for quick clean-ups and small spaces,” she says. “Larger ones are preferred for larger homes or spaces and require less emptying during cleaning sessions.”

How We Tested

Like all of the categories across AD Shopping, we thoroughly test and review in the appliance sector too. Our team of editors and contributors welcome top-of-the-line vacuums ranging from wet-dry to steam cleaners into our homes on a regular basis to assess how well they keep our floors clean. For these cordless vacuums, we’ve tested all of them for at least one week and some for years to ensure these home appliances hold up for the long haul. We also factored in the below to determine if the cleaners in this guide were worthwhile investments.

HEPA Filters: Our favorite cordless vacuums feature HEPA filters, which are designed to capture even the smallest of particles and allergens (usually around 99.97%). This filtration system ensures that your floors are getting their most thorough clean, while also ridding your space of irritants like dust that can cause allergy flare-ups.

Warranty: Since vacuums tend to be bigger-ticket appliances, we checked for options that boast generous warranties. We looked for options with at least one year returns available in the event that there are any issues or malfunctions.

Suction and Airflow: Arguably the most important factor in a vacuum, we kept an eye out for cleaners with strong suction power and airflow to effectively pick up dirt and debris without having to go over our floor areas with several passes.

Cleaner Heads: Since every home is bound to have some tight spaces and nooks that are hard to reach, most vacuums in this list have motorized brush rolls as well as rotating cleaner heads to thoroughly clean and navigate through your space. Plus, many cleaner heads are designed to get right up against baseboards to collect dust.

Ease of Use: Bottom line, we’re fans of intuitive vacuum cleaners that are simple to put together out of the package and use on a routine basis. While some boast smart features like AI technology to scope out the dirt on your floors from your phone, we deem them all as user-friendly appliances.

How to Care for Cordless Vacuums

It might seem counterintuitive to clean a cleaning appliance, but it’s a must to make sure your cordless vacuum is long-lasting. Read on for the best maintenance tips to follow.

Attachments: From crevice to combination tools, you’ll need to clean any and all attachments that come with your cordless vacuum to make sure they stay in their best condition. Many can be cleaned using gentle soap and water, but check the manufacturer guidelines to follow any specific cleaning techniques.

Clogs: Oftentimes brushrolls can experience clogging, which typically prevents airflow and suction altogether. While some vacuums notify you when there’s a clog, manually check after each deep clean by removing the brush roll to make sure nothing is jammed behind it.

Dust Bin: Many vacuums will also alert you when the dustbin is full. However, emptying it regularly—even before it’s at capacity—can help ensure the vacuum’s suction power stays at its strongest. Dump it directly in a trash can to help prevent excess allergens from filling the air.

Filter: Wash the filters within the vacuum and be sure to follow the manufacturer’s instructions since every vacuum is a little different. Many companies recommend replacing HEPA filters every one to two years.

Which vacuum cleaner has the best battery life?

The Samsung Bespoke Jet AI provides 100 minutes on a single charge, so it has the longest battery life without swapping out batteries. At its heels, the DREAME R20 Cordless Vacuum has a battery life of 90 minutes. And Tineco Pure ONE can extend your cleaning session to 70 minutes.

How do you clean a cordless stick vacuum?

Specific instructions may vary by manufacturer and model, but as a general rule, you should remove and empty the dust bin (if it’s not a self-cleaning vacuum) into the trash and clean any trapped debris. Remove and rinse the filters or wash with soapy water according to directions. Clean the brush heads and accessories by first removing any debris, and then rinsing under running water. Never submerge the main body containing the motor in water.

What are the best cordless stick vacuums for pet hair?

Several cordless stick vacuums are ideal for pet hair. The LG Cord Zero offers the right combo of power, suction, and lights to see hidden pet hair. The compressor also packs pet hair down so you don’t have to stop and empty the dust bin so often. The Samsung Bespoke Jet is another powerful option that has an anti-tangle pet hair tool for removing pet hair from various surfaces. The Dyson Gen5 Detect Absolute has a digital motorbar cleaning head with 56 detangling vanes to remove wrapped hair, along with a hair screw tool attachment for pet beds. Last but not least, the Bissell Cleanview Pet has a tangle-free brushroll, LED lights on its floor head, and a deep cleaning fur brush.

What is a good suction power for a cordless vacuum cleaner?

The last thing you want is a vacuum cleaner that can’t actually pick anything up. That’s where the suction power comes in. For cordless stick vacuums, look for air watts (AW)---it measures suction power and air flow. Ideally, a solid model should have at least 100 AW, but if you have pets, you want this metric to be at least 150 to 200 AW.

What should you keep in mind about vacuum cleaner accessories?

Many of the vacuum cleaners on our list come with replacement brushes and specialty cleaning solutions. While it may seem like a nuisance to replace these, you’re actually extending the life of your vacuum and its cleaning abilities. Updating accessories, such as roll brushes, is especially valuable when you invest in a higher line model. Keep in mind that cleaning solutions are usually made specific to each brand and model. Trust us: You don’t want to end up with a sudsy disaster by adding in the wrong floor cleaner.
